Award.AwardTitle: R/V Marcus G Langseth - Oceanographic Instrumentation 2020
Award.AbstractNarration: The instrumentation request in this proposal is to replace the seismic source controller system and associated equipment on Langseth. The equipment is beyond end of life and no longer supported by the vendor. This system is critical to marine seismic acquisition on the vessel. The new system is a commonly used industry source controller that is manufacturer supported. All instrumentation is for shared use among all National Science Foundation funded researchers<br/><br/>GunLink 2K Source Controller $988,264 <br/><br/><br/>Broader Impacts<br/>The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The R/V Marcus G. Langseth is a Columbia University owned and operated reseach vessel that is part of the US Academic Research Fleet (ARF). It brings a  unique capability to the ARF for 2 and 3-dimenstional seismic imaging of the sub-seafloor in areas critical for looking at a variety of fundamental earth processes and geohazards. These images provide information for 10's of kilometers into the earth's crust.

The 2020 Oceanographic Instrumentation award provided $600,000 that funded the critical replacement and upgrade of the seismic  source controller equipment for the Langseth marine multichannel seismic (MCS) system.  This source controller is key to being able to manage the timing of the seismic source  bring triggered which is at the heart of the seismic imaging that the R/V Langseth provides.

The funding from this award allowed us to purchase a GunLink 2000 system and all the associated components. The Gunlink system is an industry standard one with parts that are easily available. It is significantly cheaper to operate and reduces the maintenance costs associated compared with the former ION Digishot system. It's broad compatibility with other modern systems also means that our marine techs and any contractors are also familiar with this equipment as well.  

The system was ordered in fall 2020 and completetly installed by February 2021 and tested at the pier. Following a training course for all of the LDEO marine techs on tthe GunLink system,  it's first full deployment was for the Cascadia Margin program in June/July 2021. The system worked very well and reliably for this project and represents a huge upgrade for the scientists that use the seismic system.
